717200f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south across Warren Street, showing the building frontage that faces City Hall Park (leftl. Warren Street is to the right center. Beyond are Park Place and Barclay Streets. The spire of St. Pauls Chapel o'ertowers the buildings lying between the last two thoroughfares.
About 1870
American Studio, photo
B7 Nassau Street, N.Y.C.
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RICRIE URENO7N

717201f-a.text:
Broadway, at the S. W. corner of Warren Street, as photographed from the enclosed City Hall Park. Note the posters on one of the stone gate supports. They read "Murder-Rom(an)Catholics" and "California". The riot of 1871 caused by the attact of the Irish Catholics on the parading Orangemen, and the Gold Rush to California leads the writer to the concluded
date of 1871 instead of the given 1854.
1871
Girt of Urbrock Collection

717209f-a.text:
Broadway, north from and including Warren Street (left) showing the horse drawn traffic upon this cobble stoned thoroughfare. On the right appears City Hall Park and the A.T. Stewart Building. The building on the extreme left is the present Rogers, Peet and Co. Building which at the time this photo was taken was occupied by Devlin and Co., Clothiers.
About 1888.
Brown Brothers.

717210f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Warren (left) Street. On the right across a corner of City Hall Park is the 7-story Sun Building (formerly Stewarts).
1925.

Broadway and Warren Street.

717183f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from Warren Street, to and including Park Place, as viewed across City Hall Park from the Municipal Building. Shown on the extreme left, is a portion of the Woolworth Building( south west corner of Park Place). The New York Telephone Building appears silhoetted
against the Eudson River.
Jaue 3, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

717206f-a.text:
Broadway (center, buildinc fronts) west side, from Warren (left) to Chambers (right) Streets, showing at the S.W. corner of the latter point the recentl constructed (ahout 1930) office building, So. 27O Broadway. The photographer is vieing westward to the North (Hudson) River from a vantage point atop the Aunicipal Building. To the left mormin is the New York
Telephone Building on West Street.
June 23, 1933
P.L. Sperr

717181f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from Warren Street. Prominently shown, is the Woolworth Building, towering over the old United States Post Office,
at the southern end of City Hall Park.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
Neg. ~ E29S

717211f-a.text:
Mroadway, west side, north from Warren Street, as viewed from City Hall Park, (east side of Bro dway, between Mail and Chambers Streets). The 12story structure partially shown on the left, is the City Hall Building, Nos. 26O-261 Broadway, and is at the N.W. corner of Warren Street. A portion
o: the Sun Building appears on the right.
August 15, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

1509065.title: Broadway - Warren Street, east side - looking north
1509065.folder: Broadway - Warren Street, east side - looking north, Manhattan, NY

717199f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway, south from Warren Street, and showing on the east side, a portion of City Hall Park, with the United States Post Office on its southern boundary (Mail Street). Appearing across the skyline, are the 60 Wall Street Tower, the twin spires of the Park Row Building and the triangular
St. Paul Building.
November 6, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A similar view prior to the demolition of the Postoffice Building.
In May 1939 this feature will have completely disappeared.
July 4, 1938.
P. L. Sperr.
